MIKE AS HE CONTINUES DOWN THE STREET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a small, nondescript, typical eatery with a row of small booths along the outside window, a counter, and a kitchen beyond. The room is empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he walks over to a stool and sits down at the counter, reaches over, takes a menu, studies it for a moment, then turns and looks over toward the juke box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garish, multicolored, still blaring out the music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns on his stool to look toward the opening to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the glass we can see a row of six or seven pies baking and almost fully browned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike calls out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sardonically calling out) Is this thing loud enough for you out here? I mean, can you hear it all right? He grins wryly, waits momentarily for an answer that neve comes, turns and looks again at the juke box. He rises, gets off his stool, goes over the juke box, looks all around it, pushes it away from the wall a few inches, reaches back, fiddles with a knob. The music goes much lower. Then, satisfied, he pushes the machine back agains the wall and goes back over to the counter.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Kind of early for that kind of music, isn't it? Still, silence.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I noticed there's a town just up the road. What's the name of it? Again, silence. Mike puts the menu down, peers through th little opening to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small room with a couple of stoves, et cetera. He goes over to the stove, turns down the oven, and looks around the room. He goes over to a back door, tries it and it swings open. He steps back as it creaks open and reveals the diner's backyard.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (calls out) Hey? You got a customer out front! Hey! Customer here! Still no answer. Mike turns, retraces his steps to the lunch counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike still shows no real emotion beyond a puzzlement. He' neither frightened nor concerned as yet. Again he picks u the menu and studies it. He talks out loud, now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think ham and eggs. Eggs up and soft. Hash browns. Coffee. Black. (looks up, calls out again) Customer! Got a customer out front! (he rises from the stool again -- sticks his head in the kitchen) Ham and eggs. Hash browns. Coffee black. He stands there by the open, swinging door staring into t empty kitchen. His eyes dart about now and for the first time we see something beyond puzzlement on his features. What supplants it is irritation, not acute, but definitel there. He reaches into his shirt pocket and takes out a crumpled pack of cigarettes, goes back to the lunch counter. Now he scratches his head, sits down on the stoo for a long moment. Suddenly the music on the juke box stops. The sudden cessation of noise brings with it a silence even more obvious. Mike turns to stare at the juk box. He looks up at the clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is on the counter near the coffee urn, its face turned sideways so that Mike can't see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he goes over to the clock to turn it around and stare it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It reads a quarter to six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike turns away from it, but in doing so brushes against and knocks it to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the floor as Mike bends over and picks it up. The face of it is broken. He puts it back on the counter, then goe back over to his seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His fingers tap a nervous staccato on the counter top. Th silence now begins to be oppressive and nerve-racking. Suddenly, as if an afterthought, he reaches into his pock and pulls out the money, looks at it in his hand, then reaches into all his other pockets. He finds nothing. He rubs at his face again. Mike speaks aloud but obviously t no one in an attempt to make noise or sound or just to en the stillness.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Cash customer here. Hungry cash customer. (he rubs his face again) I got two dollars and eighty-five cents. (he looks at the money very thoughtfully, almost questioningly) Two dollars and eighty-five cents, American money. (then he stops and looks off in obvious puzzlement) American money. (he throws it out into the air as if to reassure himself as to the meaning of the phrase) Sure, American money. He looks at the clock again, and into the opening to the kitchen and the swinging doors, at the silent juke box, a back at the money in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Well, we got this much settled. I'm an American. (he raises his voice a little now as if to wake someone in the next room) There's a little question about my identity. Let me put it to you this way -- I'm not sure who I am. (he holds up the money) But I've got two dollars and eighty- five cents and I'm hungry. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This much is established! He gets up off the stool and suddenly slams both palms do hard on the counter, making all the salt shakers and cats bottles quiver and rattle.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (shouts) I got two dollars and eighty-five cents and I'm hungry! He stops dead now, listening to the silence that enfolds and surrounds him. Then he looks around. Again the sense irritation. He takes a drag on his cigarette, then butts out, rises, goes to the front door and stares out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The long road that leads away from the lunch counter without a sign of traffic, people, or anything. He whirls around to look back into the lunchroom.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (aloud) I'm gonna wake up in a minute. I know I'm gonna wake up. I wish... I wish there'd be a noise or something to wake me up. He suddenly sticks two fingers in his mouth and whistles, listens for a moment, then he whistles again, kind of grinning to himself.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: A little noise, please! (now he sings at the top of his voice) "Yes sir, that's my baby. No sir, don't mean maybe. Yes sir, that's my baby now!" He laughs a little sheepishly, listens for a moment to th silence, then he turns and goes back to the lunch counter

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike sits down, buries his face in his hands, rubbing his eyes, massaging his temples as if trying to force out wit  his fingers some connective link... some reassurance of existence... some knowledge of where he is and what he's doing. Once again he looks around the room.

dialogues.speaker: HIS EYES
dialogues.text: Taking in the shots of the coffee urn, the menus, the sal and pepper shakers, all the simple, commonplace, terribly normal adjuncts to what should be a normal scene but somehow isn't. He rises now, looks around again, then wal to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he slowly reaches down and turns the sign over to read CLOSED. Then he walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's still early morning, and what we're looking at is th main drag of a small town, flanked by stores, a courthous a post office, et al. The most singularly overwhelming feature of this is the complete absence of motion and all noise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he walks down the sidewalk looking from one side of th street to the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Past stores as Mike goes by them. Drugstore, grocery, sod bar. Most of the doors are open and there are lights on inside, but there are no people. There's an odd, indefinable feeling that permeates the scene, a sense of activity and yet coming with no players, and no people, a if it was a place full of motion and movement suddenly stripped of the people performing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Mike's point of view. It is devoid of any kind of movement whatsoever. It is absolutely quiet. Over this  tableau we superimpose the title, "Where Is Everybody?" along with major credits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he stops and looks around. He is suddenly startled by the sound of chimes. He whirls around and looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As it rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shades his eyes to search out the church and then, in turning away from it, he stops abruptly, staring at something across the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little clothing store and alongside of it an alley wher a large delivery truck is parked. In the cab, in the passenger- seat, a human figure can be seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking down as Mike goes to the curb, cranes his neck to look over to the truck.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Hey, miss? Miss? (he makes a gesture that is part a wave, part an attempt at reassurance) Over here, miss. Look, I wonder if you could do me a favor? I don't want you to think I'm nuts or anything. I mean, it's nothing like that. It's just that -- (again he grins a little) I don't seem to remember who I am. It's the craziest thing. I've looked all around and I haven't seen anybody around. I guess it's just early or something. Literally there hasn't been a soul. (he takes a step off the curb, looks again toward the (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: cab of the truck, a little puzzled. He smiles again.) You know, it's a real oddball thing but... well, I woke up this morning... (he stops and rubs his jaw) I didn't exactly wake up. I just sort of found myself on the road walking. (and then suddenly) Amnesia, that's what they call it, isn't it? Amnesia? Well that must be what I've got. I just don't remember a thing... I can't find anybody to ask...

dialogues.speaker: SHOT
dialogues.text: As he starts to walk across the street.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (as he walks) You're the first person I've seen. Look, I really don't want you to be frightened or anything, but I was wondering if you could just tell me if maybe there's a doctor or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he stops dead in his tracks. He's about ten feet from the truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The female figure is outlined in the passenger seat but very much in the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he gets close to the cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they suddenly narrow in reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the door handle as he suddenly yanks the door open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The female figure suddenly slumps down in the seat, her head sticking out of the open door, the hair cascading down. The camera pans slowly across her body until it sto at what should be arms. There are no arms. Mike reaches over, grabs at the hair of the figure and pulls it up and around, to stare into the wooden face of a mannequin. He very slowly lets loose and the mannequin tumbles back ont the seat and then down to the floor of the cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: he mannequin staring up with glassy, manufactured eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he slowly backs away, then turns to read the lettering printed on the side of the truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It reads, RESNICK'S STORE MANNEQUINS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As his lips form the words that he's read. Then he turns look through the window of the cab at the figure of the mannequin, He takes a few steps over to her and then very gently picks her up and sets her back on the seat.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I'm very sorry, Madame. I can assure you that at no time did I mean to be so upsetting. As a matter of fact I've always had a kind of secret yen for quiet women. (then he grins) You get what I mean, Babe? (he kisses his fingertips and then plants them on the mannequin's nose) Now don't take any wooden boy friends. Then he looks at her again for a more pensive moment as i unspoken now were his earnest wish that this creature wa alive and could be talked to. He turns away and walks bac across the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he walks.

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS MIKE WALKING
dialogues.text: In different sections and on different streets. The last scene ends with him stopping abruptly to stare at somethi down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out in front is a glass-enclosed public phone booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he walks toward the gas station and goes into the phon booth.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Look, I wonder if anyone there could tell me -- He stops abruptly, grins, shakes his head, slaps at the side of his head with an open palm, fishes in his pocket and takes out a coin, deposits it in the phone, then dial the operator. He listens to the dial tone that comes on a off with dull regularity. He jiggles the receiver impatiently.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Operator. Operator. Will you listen to me? He pounds on the phone and then just indiscriminately dia a bunch of numbers. He's about to throw down the phone in disgust when suddenly at the other end of the line he hea a dial tone ringing. He very slowly and very gratefully picks up the phone now and hears a voice filtered at the other end.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: (filtered) This is the Special Operator. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The number you have reached is not a working number. Please make sure you have the right number and are dialing it correctly. Mike starts to shout into the phone.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Is everybody asleep over there? What kind of operation do you people run? Then she repeats all she's just said as Mike listens to her, excited beyond words that he has found someone alive When she finishes repeating the message he grabs the phon and is about to speak when suddenly he hears the Operator voice again.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: This is a recording. There is a certain suggestion of tenseness that suddenly shows on Mike's face.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: (filtered) This is the Special Operator. The number you have reached is not a working number. Please make sure you have the right number and are dialing it correctly.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: A recording? (he pounds on the receiver hook and shouts) Operator! Look, all I want to know is where I am. I just want to know the name of this place. Then he slowly lets the receiver loose and it hangs down from the phone box. Mike's hand touches and then grasps a telephone book, a thin one that he grabs and looks at hungrily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On it is written OAKWOOD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rips open the cover, looks down at the first page.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: A. Abel. Ackerman. Adams. Allenby. Arnold. All right, boys, where are you? (his voice is a little edgier now) Where do you all live? Just in this book here? (he rips the page open) Baker. Beldon. Biltmore. Botsford. Well, look, gang -- who's watching the store? He suddenly turns to look out at the street. FULL SHOT THE STREET MIKE'S P.O.V.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Who's watching any of the stores? He lets loose of the phone book now, lets it fall to the floor, and stands there motionless for a moment, deep in thought. Then he automatically reaches for the door handl turns it, and pushes. Nothing happens. He tries again and it remains locked. He waits a moment, then puts all his weight against it. It does not yield. It is more than irritation that we see on Mike's face now. There's the first suggestion of a real concern. He looks around his strange, glass prison.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: All right. Who's the wise guy? Who locked the door? (he tries the door once again) It's a great gag. He pounds again and then suddenly stops and looks all around. PAN SHOT FROM MIKE'S P.O.V. From inside the phone booth. The camera moves all the way  around the glass, almost in a three hundred and sixty- degree pan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He laughs softly, shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Trapped in a phone booth! Trapped in a glass phone booth, like a goldfish. (then he suddenly calls out) Well, here I am! You got me! Everybody come see! I'm right here on display!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the phone booth, as once again he starts to pound on t glass.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: How about a hand, somebody? A little assistance -- how about it? This is an absolutely hysterical town, and I'm growing very fond of it, but I'd appreciate it if He stops abruptly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he stares at something through the glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half-smoked and still burning, lying on the sidewalk just outside the booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking into Mike's face through the glass. For the very first time there's a look of incipient fear.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Look. Whoever's out there. This isn't funny any more. You understand? I don't like this jazz. It's getting dull. (he looks around again) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I know I can be heard. I know... I know somebody's watching me. Immediately after he's said this he realizes he has suddenly given voice to his fear. He's labeled what is beginning to bother him. Simply a sense of being watched. He suddenly bends down, picks up the phone book, flings i against the glass of the door. The glass disintegrates. Mike sticks his hand through, opens the door from the outside, then kicks at it with his foot. It springs open and halfway off its hinges as he goes out onto the street Then he looks down at his hand. It's cut; a rivulet of blood runs down through the fingers. He feels for a handkerchief, takes it and wraps it around the hand. He squeezes it a couple of times, trying to get more blood t flow. Then he starts down the street again. LONG SHOT STREET MIKE'S P.O.V. Once again the sense of emptiness and loneliness and that bizarre quality of activity with no actors.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE AS HE CONTINUES DOWN THE STREET
dialogues.text: He pauses in front of a building and looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which reads, POLICE STATION.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks up the steps and into the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a small anteroom, and then an open, barred door which leads to a corridor lined with cells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he enters and looks around. There is a police sergeant desk, files, pictures of wanted men on the wall. A telety machine hums in the corner. Mike goes to look at it. The light over it is on, but nothing is being written. He whirls around and stares toward the sergeant's desk, goes behind it, picks up a microphone, fingers it for a moment  then talks into it.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Calling all cars. Calling all cars. Unknown man walking around the police station. Suspicious looking character. Probably wanted by the FBI -- Then he stops, looks at the mike, chuckles softly for a moment and then stops abruptly, the smile gone. He flings the microphone away from him and looks slowly around the room.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I wish I could shake that feeling... (he looks around again) That crazy feeling of being watched... listened to... He stares toward the cell doors then begins to walk slowl toward them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he stands in the middle of the next room, looking from empty cell to empty cell. Then he whirls around at a bubbling sound. There, on a hot plate, is a pot of coffee perking. Behind him we see the barred door leading to the anteroom begin to close. Mike's eyes look wild, as if subconsciously he realizes he's in danger. He whirls arou to see the cell door closing and then, with a shout, thro himself against it, pushing it away before it locks. He seems to hang on it now, breathing deeply.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: All right, time to wake up! Time to wake up now! He whirls around, his face distorted, close up against th camera. He shouts.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Time to wake up! He stumbles through the anteroom and then back to the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking down at Mike as he stands in the middle of the empty street, the stores around him, the quiet. He sudden screams.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Where is everybody? Where is everybody!?

dialogues.speaker: FILM CLIP A HOT AND HIGH AFTERNOON SUN
dialogues.text: Shimmering in a sea of heatwaves. The camera sweeps down until it is level with the street and a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he sits on a curb, staring dully and numbly across at nothing. The church steeple clock sounds two. He looks up listens to it, but is no longer shocked by it. He just le the sound of the chimes play along the edges of his consciousness without really being aware of them. Now he rises and walks slowly, methodically, without much appare purpose across the street. He looks up to see a sign reading DRUGSTORE. He enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is light and cheerful inside. On the left hand side is the soda bar with a big mirror behind it full of stickers advertising various concoctions -- soft drinks, ice cream sandwiches. Mike, as he enters, pauses by the cigarette a candy counter. He looks through the glass for a long moment, then reaches behind and takes out a couple of cigars. He unwraps one, sticks it in his mouth, lights it takes a couple of draws, butts it out, reaches in another box, takes one of those, then looks in the box.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Two for a dollar. Now that's more like it. I always like an expensive cigar. Then he turns with a smile and says to nobody.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: How about you guys -- any of you want a cigar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he gets up on a stool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take a chocolate soda with chocolate ice cream. He starts to laugh, but the laugh is checked almost immediately as he sees his reflection in the mirror behin the counter. His fingers run exploringly across his face, taking in the beard stubble, the hollowness beneath the eyes, the strange, haunted, frightened look that is obvio there. He looks at himself again for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: You'll forgive me, old pal, but I don't recollect the name. The face seems vaguely familiar... but it's the name that escapes me. (a pause) I'1l tell you what my problem is. I'm in the middle of a nightmare that I can't wake up from. (he points to the reflection) You're part of it. You and the ice cream and the cigar. That police station and the phone booth. That little mannequin. This whole bloody town, wherever it is. (a pause) Whatever it is. I just remembered something. Scrooge said it. You remember Scrooge, old buddy? Ebenezer Scrooge? It's what he said to the ghost, Jacob Marley. he said, "You may be an undigested bit of beef, a blot of mustard, a crumb of cheese, a fragment of an undone potato. There's more of gravy than of grave about you." You see? That's what you all are. You're what I had for dinner last night. You must be. But now I'd like to wake up. I've had it... I'd like to wake up now. And if I can't wake up, at least I'd like... I'd like to find somebody to talk to. He rises now and goes behind the counter. He starts to fi himself a chocolate soda, experimenting with some of the cupboards until he finds the right ingredients, the ice cream, the milk, et cetera. Then he mixes himself a soda, tall, frosty, delicious. He starts to sip it with a stra as he walks around the drugstore. He stops by a poster of high school football schedule.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he takes it in one hand and reads it as he sips the soda. But the normality of it suddenly points out the incongruity of what he's living through. He puts the post back on the counter, shaking his head, staring at it.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I must be a very imaginative guy. Very imaginative. Nobody in the whole world can have a dream as... as complete as mine. Right down to the last detail. (he taps the poster) Right down to the last detail. He turns, stares across at a big magazine rack near the front window of the store. He crosses over to it, stares down at some of the magazines, then kneels down, interested. He begins to trace the dates on each one of t magazines. The majority of them say October 1958 and his mouth forms that phrase, "October 1958." Then he bites his lips, shakes his head again, rises, loo down at the group of comic books, each with a lurid title having to do with horror themes, Spook themes, et cetera. Then suddenly he stops and looks down at one, the cover o which is peeping out from behind the others and whose tit is visible. He reaches down and pulls it out just a few inches farther so that he can read the entire title.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The title: The Last Man on Earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks it up and stares at the cover, then flings it do on the floor. He turns rapidly away and heads back to the counter where he puts the soda down. He is suddenly grip by another spasm of such utter loneliness that it forces him out onto the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera follows him out of the store. As he gets out on th street he suddenly shouts, shrilly, illogically.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (shouting) Hey! Hey, anybody! Anybody hear me? Anybody hear me? He almost lurches to the other side of the street where h buries his face against the window of a building. When hi head goes back he sees the letters U.S. POST OFFICE and h starts to laugh again.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Any mail for me? Anybody write me a letter? I don't know what my name is, but maybe you can tell me in there, huh? Will you tell me what my name is? He pounds his fist against the glass and then suddenly ha to stifle what obviously is a sob as he begins to give in to the loneliness and to the unknown and to the pulsating gnawing fear that envelops him. Then he turns away from t window, struggling for composure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at something across the street. Camera sweeps wi until it stops on --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a sign reading CITY BANK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he gets up off the bench, walks across the street, and into the bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he walks past all the tellers' cages. He stops at the end of the line, presses his face against the bars.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I'd like to borrow about eight hundred thousand dollars. How about it? (then he nods and grins) Thanks. I think that's generous of you. I think that's really generous. He pulls the bars up, reaches in and takes two packages o money. Then he starts to retrace his steps toward the fro door. He's about to leave when he looks toward the first teller's window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes some of the bills that he's crammed into his shi pocket, throws them away.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Gotta make room for some silver. He goes behind the teller's window and starts to cram rol of coins into his pockets. Then suddenly his eyes look wi again as he looks up, his eyes scanning the room. And again, illogically, the same mixture of wisdom and paranoia.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Somebody watching me? He goes out in front of the teller's cage again and looks around.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Somebody watching me? He looks up toward the ceiling and around as if expecting to see someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crazy feeling. Crazy, odd-ball feeling. Like... like I knew someone was watching me. And then his eyes narrow again in an awareness of danger.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Watching me... and trying to button me up someplace. Trying to trap me. He looks around wildly again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he starts to run toward the door. He trips over some sort of a lever close to the teller's cage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the wall as it begins to ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he stops by the front door and whirls around as the loud, dissonant clanging pierces the quiet. Then he whirl around and tries the front door again. It's locked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bell. Teller's cage. Locked door. Mike's hand. Mike's fac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he races toward the alarm on the wall. He grabs the wires that extend from it and suddenly yanks on them, pulling them apart. The bell abruptly stops. Then he whir around and stares at the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is now ajar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he goes back toward the teller's cage, grabs the coins and bills, crams them back into his pocket. He walks towa the open door, then out onto the street again, leaving a trail of silver and bills behind him. He sits down on th curb, unwraps the handkerchief from around his hand, wipe his face with it. He reaches into his pocket, takes out a crumpled fistful of bills, takes one out, grins at it, takes out the remnants of a cigar, sticks the cigar in hi mouth, takes the bill, lights it.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Here's something I've always wanted to do. Always wanted to do this. He takes the lit bill and lights a cigar with it, then he lets loose of the burning bill and watches it flutter to the ground and disappear in ashes. Mike watches it burn, and then slowly his face looks tired, hopeless.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Big deal. So what? Big deal. He lets his head hang a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As it suddenly goes on. Camera then pans down for a

dialogues.speaker: SHOT OF MIKE
dialogues.text: On a bench looking up toward the light. Then he turns to look toward the street flanking the square. The lights ha gone on in front of all the stores and in the windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reacting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the lights go on around it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks across the street, stops by the ticket window, a then, almost dreamlike, speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like one tick -- Then he stops, shakes his head, closes his eyes, realizin how ludicrous this is. He is about to go in when he suddenly stops and stares at a poster advertising the movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which shows an air force pilot in his coveralls advertisi the movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he suddenly feels his own outfit and gradually makes t connection that the uniform of the man in the picture is similar to that which he wears.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Air force. Air force. (then he whirls around, looks up toward the sky) Air force. I'm air force. (he once again looks down at his coveralls and feels them, grabs at them) Air force. I'm in the air force.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he walks from the outside of the theater, through the lobby, on into the interior.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (shouting) Hey, everybody. I'm in the air force. I remember that much. I'm in the air force. Does anybody hear me? I'm in the air force. And then once again he rubs his eyes, runs a hand wildly across his face and then suddenly surveys the theater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are enough lights on to cast a soft orange glow  through the room. He looks around at the absolute, vast emptiness of the place. Then he sits down, checks his watch, looks up at the big white screen with nothing on i He looks at his watch again and then settles down in the chair, his eyes closed, and he starts to succumb to the fatigue that sweeps over him.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Air force. What does that mean? Was there a bomb or something? Is that what happened? That must have been it, a bomb. But if there was a bomb -- (he looks around the empty theater now) It would have destroyed everything. And nothing is destroyed. Suddenly he is aware of the lights lowering. He starts an his eyes open wide in time to see the last of the lights down. A long beam of white light shines from the projecti booth and suddenly on the screen appears a big introducto title, Cartoon Parade, with appropriate march music. Mike leaps to his feet, looks from the projection booth down t the screen. He suddenly starts to run down the aisle, shouting.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Hey! Hey, somebody up there? He stops in front of the projectionist's light so that we get an almost nightmarish picture of the cartoons partially showing on his face and body as he screams.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Hey, somebody up there? Who's running the pictures? Can you see me? Can you see me up there? Hey! Then he races back up the aisle, arriving at the rear of the theater. He looks wildly around, then he sees a door with a glass window, steps visible on the other side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he races up them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he bursts inside. The picture is running from one of t two projectors, but the room is absolutely empty. Mike races over to the machine, bends down and peers at it as the film goes through and he hears the sound of the carto music and voices. This is too much for him. He throws himself against the wall, peering out of the small, circular hole that the picture shoots through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of the vast, empty theater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns away, goes out the door, stumbling down the step

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He continues down the steps and out into the lobby again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops for a moment and looks across the lobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is at this moment making popcorn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he closes his eyes, shakes his head. Then he opens the His eyes go wide. He starts to run toward the camera, coming up very close and almost at the point of impact we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of Mike and a mirror as he smashes his face and hands against it and then recoils from the reflection, backs of a few feet, and then looks at the mirror on the opposite side of the room. The combination throws off reflections almost to infinity. He looks from left to right staring a the hundreds of Mike Ferrises who ape him in his every movement. Then he stops and looks across at the refreshme stand where the popcorn continues to pop in the big container. This, too, is more than he can stand. His fac screws up like a small child about to cry, and then he shouts.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Oh my God. Oh my dear God! He stumbles through the lobby and out into the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stumbles down the street aimlessly now, intent only on moving, not finding. His footsteps start to drag and finally he stops, sits down on the curb, buries his face his hands, rubs his eyes. Then he looks up to once again find himself looking through the drugstore window, the magazine that he'd been reading lies on the floor face up

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking down through the window, distorting the cover of the magazine in such a manner as to make the lettering appear big and irregular. Once again the title slaps at h across the face. The Last Man on Earth. He rises slowly, backing away from the window, shaking his head. He turns and races across the street. Suddenly, then, he stops abruptly as the light on the corner changes to red and he instinctively comes to a halt. And then he stops dead, realizing once again the ludicrousness of it. He begins t laugh -- the laughter becomes convulsive, wild. All the w across the street he continues it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he goes by all the stores that we've been introduced t As he goes by each one a sound emanates from it, a sound way out of proportion to what it actually should be. When he passes the pool hall we hear the mammoth bowling alley sound echoing from it. From in front of the theater comes cacophony of music and laughter. From the drug store ther is a fizzling, bubbling sound of drinks. From the record store, the dissonant, blaring sound of music. As each noi joins in it becomes mumbled and part of a big morass of noise. Gradually the very dimension of it so frightens and shock Mike that he begins to back away from each store as he  passes -- it as if being assaulted on all sides. He stumbles against a street post, whirls around, frightened stares at it, and then suddenly, almost supplicatingly, throws his arms around it, buries his face against it. He starts to sob.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Won't somebody help me? Won't somebody please help me? Then his sobs subside and he stands there, breathing deeply. His eyes slowly open. Sweat stands out on his features. He looks haggard, desperate, close to cracking. The noise somehow, for no apparent reason, suddenly stops and there's a deep, dead, all-pervading silence again. Mike's eyes travel up the post, stare up toward the sky. squints against the sun.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Who's watching me? Who's looking at me? (screaming) Who's looking at me? He looks down toward the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves to the middle of the road again, still looking u toward the sky, and then as if suddenly seeing an adversary, begins to run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Mike backs into it, trying to get inside, reaching for the door and missing, and then slamming his face against the front pane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking from inside the store outside toward him. His eye go wide and he starts to scream.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE'S SHOULDER
dialogues.text: At a huge eye looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he starts to run away from the store again. The camera takes in a shot of an optometrist's sign with a huge eye that Mike had seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he runs back toward the post. He grabs it and holds on tight, then he looks down. His hands have touched a butto and he looks down at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a sign over it: PUSH TO TURN GREEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he looks away toward the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then suddenly Mike slams the palm of his hand against the button and punches it over and over again.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Somebody help me. Help me. Help me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As if flashes from red to green, from green to red, from red to green, over and over again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he keeps pushing the button. His voice, sobbing, screeching, plaintive, frightened.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Somebody help me. Please. Please, help me

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pushing a button on an instrument panel. The camera dolli away until both the back of the panel and Mike's face are on a small television screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down a line of officers in a viewing room as they intentl watch the screen. We hear Mike's voice as it coincides wi a red light that flashes brilliantly on and off over the viewing screen.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Please. Please help me. Help me. A general, obviously in command, turns to his aide on his right.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL
dialogues.text: Clock him! (and then turning to his left says to the officer alongside) Get him out of there, quick! Officer two reaches over for a hand mike. Pushes the button.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER TWO
dialogues.text: Release the subject! On the double!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the center of it, illuminated by a couple of spots in otherwise dark room, is a small, hermetically sealed meta box about six by five feet and about five feet high. A sliding panel is pushed back. Several air force men reach down and start unstrapping Mike and then carefully lift h through the hole. A white-clad medical officer begins to remove electrodes that have been taped to his body at various points. By this time Mike has stopped speaking. H eyes are half closed. He breathes deeply and irregularly, slumps forward in his seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smashed against the instrument panel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the broken glass covering a clock on the panel which reads six fifteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they remove him.

dialogues.speaker: AIR FORCE MAN ONE
dialogues.text: Be careful. He's cut his hand on that clock glass there --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they hurriedly approach the scene, their footsteps ringing hollowly on the concrete floor.

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL OFFICER
dialogues.text: He's all right, sir. Delusions of some sort. I guess that's it. He's coming out of it now.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL
dialogues.text: (nods) Fine. You get all your data recorded?

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL OFFICER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Every bit of it.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL
dialogues.text: (to Officer One who comes up from behind) Did you get him clocked?

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER ONE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Four hundred and eighty four hours, thirty-six minutes.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL
dialogues.text: Good. I'd like to get a look at all the data when they're compiled. I'd like the reaction chart on him, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto) The press, sir? He points toward the opposite side of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they stand waiting expectantly.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL
dialogues.text: On the run, if they don't mind. I want to talk to Ferris.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER TWO
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. He motions toward the press, and beckons them over as the General, the medical officers, and the others start walki in the opposite direction toward Mike Ferris, who lies on stretcher at the very far and opposite side of the room.

dialogues.speaker: THE GENERAL AND THE REPORTERS
dialogues.text: As they join him and start to walk across the room toward Ferris.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER ONE
dialogues.text: You consider it a success, sir?

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL
dialogues.text: Very much so. He's been alone in that box for something in the neighborhood of four hundred and eighty four hours, which is roughly equivalent to a trip to the moon, several orbits, and then back.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER ONE
dialogues.text: And this then was a simulated trip to the moon? Is that right, General?

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL
dialogues.text: (nods) For all intent and purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the wires attached to him?

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL
dialogues.text: Electrodes. All of his reactions have been charted and graphed. Respiration, heart action, blood pressure. At this moment they reach a point some ten feet away from where Mike Ferris lies on a stretcher attended by a coupl of medics. Their voices become low.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER THREE
dialogues.text: What happened to him toward the end? Just before he pushed that button or whatever it is.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL
dialogues.text: What happened to him was that he cracked. We assume delusions of some sort, but I'1l tell you something, gentlemen -- you spend two and a half weeks all by your lonesome in a five foot square box without ever being able to hear a human voice other than your own... I'll give you especially good odds that your imagination would run away with you too, just as his obviously did. One of the medics looks up, motions the general over. The general takes a few steps until he's very close to Mike.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL
dialogues.text: How do you feel, son?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (his voice is weak but he's obviously much improved now) I feel much better, sir. I'm sorry about... toward the end.

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL OFFICER
dialogues.text: (close by) What was it like, Ferris? Where did you think you were?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks from one to the other, wets his lips) Some place I don't want to visit again. A town... a town without people. Without anybody.

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL OFFICER
dialogues.text: And you had to get out of that town, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (nods) I sure did. (then he looks up toward the medical officer) What was the matter with me? Just off my rocker, huh?

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL OFFICER
dialogues.text: Just a kind of nightmare, Ferris, that your mind manufactured for you. The reporters lean forward straining to overhear this conversation.

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL OFFICER
dialogues.text: You see, Ferris, we can feed stomachs with concentrates. We can supply microfilm for recreation, reading, even movies of a sort. We can pump oxygen in, waste material out. The camera now moves around so that it is shooting just over the heads of all the men assembled and is looking at the box in the background which is on the periphery of th light.

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL OFFICER
dialogues.text: But there's one thing we can't simulate. That's a pretty basic need -- man's hunger for companionship, the barrier of loneliness. That's one we haven't licked yet. At this moment the medics help Ferris to his feet. He stands there motionless for a moment as if testing newfou legs, and then he looks out toward the open hangar door a  the night sky.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Next time though... it won't be just a box and a hangar, will it?

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL
dialogues.text: (going to his side and looking out toward the sky with him) No, Mike. Next time you'll really be alone. There's a long, thoughtful silence as Mike takes a few steps toward the hangar door. He pauses for a moment near the box. A side has been removed so that he's staring directly into the control panel where the broken clock ca be seen still reading six fifteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he reacts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the camera pans over the broken clock, a microphone which hangs by the cord, a small microfilm apparatus, et cetera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he looks away and then continues to walk over to the hangar door. He slowly looks up toward the sky and the camera sweeps up for a long shot of the moon hanging brig and lustrous in the sky.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (grins thoughtfully, stares up toward the silver orb, and then quietly) Don't go away up there. Next time... next time it won't be a nightmare or a dream. Next time it'll be real. So don't go away... We'll be there in a little while. Then he starts to walk out in the night followed by the others. The camera begins a slow pan back into the room until it is shooting on the box, squatting empty and  impassive in the empty room.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR'S VOICE
dialogues.text: The barrier of loneliness. The palpable, desperate need of the human animal to be with his fellow man.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT SKY
dialogues.text: The moon and the stars.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Up there... up there is the vastness of space, in the void that is sky... up there is an enemy known as isolation. It sits there in the stars waiting... waiting with the patience of eons... forever waiting... in the Twilight Zone.
